key_insight: Architectural differences between uniform and trainable attention (the 'Clock' vs 'Pizza' interpretations) do not produce distinct algorithms for modular addition; both implement the same algorithm via topologically and geometrically equivalent internal representations.
problem_solved: Addresses whether different attention designs yield fundamentally different computation circuits for modular addition, resolving conflicting interpretations by comparing representations at the manifold/topological level rather than individual neurons.
method: Compare internal representations produced by uniform and learnable-attention models on modular addition tasks using geometric and topological tools.
Align and quantify manifolds (e.g., embedding visualization, metric comparisons, and topological invariants) to test equivalence of representational geometry.
Perform circuit-level analyses and empirical validation to show mapping between the two architectures' representations and the shared algorithm they implement.
impact: Shows that architecture-level differences need not imply different algorithms, encouraging interpretability that focuses on representation geometry/topology and enabling practitioners to reason about functional equivalence across model designs.
visual_elements: Side-by-side schematic of 'Clock' vs 'Pizza' circuits with arrows showing mapping between components
3D/2D manifold embeddings (color-coded by input/output) demonstrating overlapping geometry for both architectures
Topological summary (e.g., persistence diagram or simple invariants) highlighting matching topology across representations
Pipeline flowchart: input modular addition → model representations → geometric/topological comparison → conclusion of equivalence
paper_title: On the geometry and topology of representations: the manifolds of modular addition
paper_authors: Gabriela Moisescu-Pareja, Gavin McCracken, Harley Wiltzer, Vincent Létourneau, Colin Daniels
